@oddM [τ, µ]  where can I find *all* tempos and calculations to instruct my dancers?

```
def get_epoch_containing_block(block: int, netuid: int, tempo: int = 360) -> range:
    """
    Reimplementing the logic from subtensor's Rust function:
        pub fn blocks_until_next_epoch(netuid: u16, tempo: u16, block_number: u64) -> u64
    See https://github.com/opentensor/subtensor.

    See also: https://github.com/opentensor/bittensor/pull/2168/commits/9e8745447394669c03d9445373920f251630b6b8

    If given block happens to be an end of an epoch, the resulting epoch will end with it. The beginning of an epoch
    is the first block when values like "dividends" are different (before an epoch they are constant for a full
    tempo).
    """
    assert tempo > 0

    interval = tempo + 1
    last_epoch = block - 1 - (block + netuid + 1) % interval
    next_tempo_block_start = last_epoch + interval
    return range(last_epoch, next_tempo_block_start)


def get_cycle_containing_block(block: int, netuid: int, tempo: int = 360) -> range:
    """
    A cycle contains two epochs, starts on an even one. A cycle is the basic unit of passage of time in compute horde,
    and validators testing miners are synchronised to cycles.
    """
    very_first_epoch = get_epoch_containing_block(0, netuid, tempo=tempo)
    epoch_containing_block = get_epoch_containing_block(block, netuid, tempo=tempo)

    if ((epoch_containing_block.start - very_first_epoch.start) / (tempo + 1)) % 2:
        # that's the second epoch in this cycle
        first_epoch = range(
            epoch_containing_block.start - (tempo + 1), epoch_containing_block.stop - (tempo + 1)
        )
        second_epoch = epoch_containing_block
    else:
        first_epoch = epoch_containing_block
        second_epoch = range(
            epoch_containing_block.start + (tempo + 1), epoch_containing_block.stop + (tempo + 1)
        )

    return range(first_epoch.start, second_epoch.stop)
```

I've read it 3 times and I still don't get it, but let me put it yet another way. TAO holders have the right to the resources provided by the subnets - on some subnets it's access to OpenAI API, on some it's a 3D asset generator, some make images, we used to have a storage subnet (remembering and recalling things is a form of intelligence) and here in sn12 the type of goods is GPU compute. As it happens the TAO holders rarely access the resources they have the right to directly - they usually delegate their stake to validators, which, for a fee, run the validator infrastructure necessary to access the resources provided by the subnets (and, well, a stake-proportional chunk of 41% of subnet emissions). Those validators on many subnets need to run on GPU hardware. At 32 subnets or so, some of the validators could no longer afford the A100 cards needed to validate sn1 and many subnets were running their validators on a single GPU which was not enough to validate all the traffic miners can send them, which brought uid pressure (a bad thing for a subnet to have) and other issues... So hardware requirements of subnets are increasing, but we are growing the number of subnets, so the same budget the validator has is getting spread thinner and thinner. In #☯・rao (to be deployed by the end of the year) we want the subnet limit to be at ~1000 (with dynamic tempo, but that's another story).

Validators have stake and a need of compute for validation. sn12 is the solution.

Along with validation support we'll actually deliver something else on the way - verifiable LLM inference. Some subnet validators need that, but it's not only them.

So this subnet is to provide validators compute. They already get 41% of emissions and thats not enough to pay for costs. okay, I can grant the point.

Are validators using it?

The initial version of the subnet provided compute and the means to consume it. We even did a nice website where you could run LLMs, video stabilization etc, but validators (on all subnets) don't yet build products and market them. I mean some of them are building these marketplaces, we've exposed APIs, we wrote a client library, one can build a product on it in a couple of days. It was around that time when we realized validators need to use GPU compute internally and we've researched and pivoted into that about a month ago.
integration with the first couple of subnets will be more difficult than the rest of them, but we'll get there. sn9 is first in line, already being implemented in parallel to the release

there have been a couple of other things along the way, such as the subnet starting with 1 executor per uid (so max of 200) and later when multiple executors per uid were released we thought it's going to be like a thousand GPUs, but one day someone just brought a ton more and the code tested on 200 is now running at 14000

Announcement: Support for A6000 Executor Class Now Available

We are pleased to announce the release of the final changes required to support the A6000 executor class. The new class name is `always_on.llm.a6000` (or `ExecutorClass.always_on__llm__a6000` in Python enum).

To enable validators to support this new class, an additional machine with an A6000 GPU must be set up, along with two S3 buckets. We refer to this machine as the "trusted miner." The trusted miner has two primary tasks:

1. Generate files containing prompts for the LLM model and store them in the prompts bucket.
2. Generate answers to a sample of prompts from these files using a specific seed value.

During regular mining operations, miners will receive an S3 link to the prompt file and a seed value. They will then upload their answers to the answers bucket. This system works efficiently because validators only need to compute a small sample of prompts.

For detailed instructions on setting up the trusted miner machine, configuring S3 buckets, and updating validator configurations, please refer to our updated validator installation guide: https://github.com/backend-developers-ltd/ComputeHorde/tree/master?tab=readme-ov-file#validator

This guide includes upgrade information, along with convenient one-liner commands for setting up the trusted miner and provisioning S3 buckets. Once the validator configuration is updated with the trusted miner and S3 buckets, and after a restart, it will automatically begin supporting the new executor class. It may take a few hours to generate sufficient files in the prompts bucket, but subsequent answer computations for prompt samples will be rapid.

Our debug validator (5HBVrFGy6oYhhh71m9fFGYD7zbKyAeHnWN8i8s9fJTBMCtEE) has been configured for several days and is ready to send synthetic jobs to the new class. Miners can set up this new class immediately and test its functionality (provided you're not ignoring the debug validator). Our debug miner is also configured to support the new class, allowing validators to verify correct operation (e.g., by checking the debug miner's receipts).

Miners are advised to pre-pull the Docker image `docker.io/backenddevelopersltd/compute-horde-prompt-solver:v0-latest`, as it is quite large and may cause timeouts if not already present on the machine.

Currently, 1% of the "weight budget" is reserved for the new executor class, with a limit of 2 executors per miner. As adoption of the new class increases, we will adjust the weight split and executor limit accordingly.

We look forward to seeing the implementation and benefits of this new executor class across our subnet. If you have any questions or encounter any issues, please don't hesitate to reach out for support.

I am considering using the "bug" which caused a couple of validators asking miners to do stuff at the same time, to fix a couple of problems. We'd make it so that in one testing period there would be 10 jobs in semi-random places, but ALL validators would be running it at the same time and miners, for optimal results, would have to contribute a stake-proportional amount of digital goods to the validators.
we could then lower the amount of tests per testing period from 10 down to even 1, but that could cause the miners to bring 10x more executors and our validators won't handle 200k of these

This would make it commercially unaffordable to ignore small validators (unless the small validator has below 8k stake, then it might be still ignored completely). The more stake the validator has, the more precise his measurement would be, but it will be much better than what we have today AND it also solves the problem of rewards for organic jobs (which validators, in turn, will have to give out proportionally to own stake and miner manifests)
it's a relatively small change in the code, but it would have a positive impact on the small validators, which today are more important to us than ever

if anyone thinks this is a bad idea, speak out, but if nobody has anything, then miners should start preparing to modify their manifest generator to return a stake-proportional amount of resources (it'll get info about requestor hotkey somehow)

sn12 was fighting the weight copiers and validatos were supporting that as a goal. The goal has now been achieved and their support for the current state of the subnet wavered.

The goal now is, and has been since I've heard about bittensor, to follow a plan which will _after some time_ (because it's a lot of work without slashing) generate more value from the digital goods than is being spent by Tao emission (at least on the miner side - 59% not going to production of digital commodities is a discussion for a different day (at least dtao will switch it to 50%, oof)). If we fail to do that, we should at least get close to it, meaning ~$97 of value in digital goods for $100 spent in emission.

Why would anyone (a bittensor validator, so that we don't look for an example very far) want to use untrusted compute provided by a sn12 miner? Normally, they won't, but if their system is resilient against mischief and the miner is strongly incentivized to do correct work (failures are very expensive), while using sn12 miners has benefits (of not having to run $20k/mo worth of GPU, and also superior performance on GPU-constrained subnets), they might.

If my calculations are correct, we should be able to achieve a multiplier of 1 to 30, meaning a validator with a single A6000 should be able to run validation of 30 subnets which normally require a single A6000 GPU, using sn12 resources, where a cheating miner is almost certainly detected without impacting the correctness of the validation process in 0 or 1 tempos. If they are honest but start cheating a few blocks before (the block in which we set/commit weights for the given) epoch, (and if some other subnet-specific conditions are met) we might detect them a bit too late to kick them out in the same tempo when they cheated. Someone can still burn a pile of cash to try to disrupt a validator but the worst they can achieve is to temporarily reduce validator performance down to the amount of GPUs the validator owns by itself. That being said, miners will get into bulk agreements etc, reducing the price of compute below retail, so we'll get more compute than we could normally buy if we were running a weight-equals-stake subnet and validators would spend money on compute individually.
But this is not done yet.

We don't have a working product. non-hashcat validation is still being rolled out and the direct application of A6000 to validate other subnets, while proven internally with experiments, has not been rolled out yet. Today you can't install a sn9 validator powered by sn12, which greatly outperforms the "normal" (single GPU) validators, on sn12 you still cannot run validation of sn1, sn17, sn19 etc which all suffer from uid pressure caused by 200 uids stacked with GPUs overpowering a single GPU of every validator, so they have to limit the amount of digital assets they accept from an uid to protect themselves from overload, which causes _all_ of the miners of _all_ uid-pressured subnets to fight for uids rather than improve their mining operation efficiency and quality. Miners want to go faster, but they can't. It's like reaching a top speed of a car, especially with manual transmission which has 4 or 5 gears - you know the engine could do more, but the cheap gearbox is preventing you from going any faster.

Today three validators have already deployed the llama-based validator, first prompts have been generated, I'm yet to check on the miners, which with 1% of the weights reserved for A6000 have not deployed a great amount of hardware. We'll be raising that number as soon as we can, pushing hashcat-based validation out and getting enough A6000 to run a proper sn9 validator, as we develop an sdk for subnet owners which will allow them to easily remove the need for the validators of their subnets to get rid of uid pressure without having any GPUs (as they'll switch to using sn12 "trusted miner" shared cards, supercharged by sn12 miners). All these things are going to be rolled out in stages over the next few weeks. Some validators are more impatient than others and I can understand that. Some don't understand the technicalities of the description above, but will understand uid pressure relief coupled with a x10 server cost in several subnets OR using sn12. Some will only understand what this is about after they see the correlation between using sn12 and having a high dividend-to-stake ratio. That's ok, we'll get there and everyone will see.

We've gone a long way. Got rid of weight copiers, developed telemetry system, receipt system, bots, dashboards, 2 communication protocols, demo website, and a bunch of other things needed to take bittensor to the next level. As @consτ [τ, τ] said, we are aiming for a thousand subnets.
The bittensor turbo is in the garage and we are installing it in the first car.
it's a different world though, in which nobody installed a turbo in any sort of vehicle yet

### Hyperparams changed on subnet 12
- `commit_reveal_weights_interval` `1` → `2`

in cooperation with the miners and validators we've found and fixed an issue which in some hard-to-pinpoint conditions a validator-miner connection broke between JobInitialRequest and JobRequest stages, causing the miner to be disqualified from scoring in that round

we added metrics which will help us diagnose the performance of the testing thread further, in anticipation of the new data confirming our suspicion of CPU starvation during the job result submission stage. If this is confirmed, we'll introduce multi-core support to that particular function to let the multi-core validators relieve the pressure by utilizing more cores

we added general system metrics to validators in order to easily observe issues such as the 100% CPU load that we've just mentioned, memory leaks, i/o problems, network overload (which we experience in JobInitialRequest phase, according to the tcpdumps we've analyzed - even the single thread we are running on right now pushes data faster than the network can take it 😎)
we added a bunch of metrics for the A6000-LLM pipeline in order to diagnose the issues they have with their pipelines

we changed the way in which we manage the work inside of the main testing thread to prevent it from blocking on cryptographic signatures of receipts and on one more thing that I don't fully understand, but it'll make the timing more reliable

we changed the way the asynchronous tasks in validators are assigned to worker processes in order to prevent cascading failures, where some type of job hangs and then weight setting also stops working
the risky part of these were running on sn12-preprod validator since Sunday, seems stable enough
we've fixed the s3 provisioning script
we are merging it all to the codebase now and deploying to the sn12-preprod for a cycle or two
then we are going to deploy a new version of both miners and validators in order to apply all of those fixes
which we'll then follow up with working with individual validators to fix their A6000-LLM pipelines, after which they'll un-CHK OTF

BTW this is something cool I'm working on with OTF - commit-reveal in sn12 was a bit unstable, they fixed it somewhat with the release today, but a new drand-based design is now in the works and that'll decrease the failure rate even further

in commit-reveal 1.0 and 2.0 the entire weight setting for commit-reveal enabled subnets (currently only sn12) can be less reliable than the old set_weights and the vtrust can suffer because of that. We've solved most of these problems already, so currently this is not causing problems for us, but 3.0 will make sn12 even more stable

We are engineers though and we chose to _do what must be done_ even if it means we need to fix stuff that we haven't written.

For quite some time we used to estimate work in order to make better informed decisions about the order of backlog items etc, but one day we noticed that the estimation meetings are taking time and the team requested that we sacrifice the estimates completely in favor of increased development speed. We've also froze all whv projects so that even the code review and deployment of these is not distracting us.

This way we'll get to learn the practical aspects of running a validator of another subnet on sn12 a couple weeks early, so that those learnings can be applied by the engineers that will, at that time, be shipping the last of the security and integration features.

The truth is that untrusted compute has massive issues in adoption. Nobody really wants to send their code and proprietary data to someone who could very well immediately sell it to your competitor. Akash, io.net, vast.ai, runpod and many others have the same problem - impressive numbers but no real adoption.

If you were on the OpenDev call today, you heard that @Swamination [τ, ?] who is responsible for the validator that OTF runs, said he has "concerns about security". Somehow he doesn't feel like using sn27 / sn51 / runpod / etc for validation, where the first thing he'd have to do, is uploading his hotkey (a literal key to the kingdom, allowing setting weights on all subnets at will) as well as API keys with high limits, to an anonymous miner. OpenAI keys used by some subnets, for example sn18, can run like $5k/mo and there's like 16 different API keys for different reasons and different subnets. The concern here is that the miner will collect the hotkey and the api keys and instead of actually running a validator for OTF, he'll illegally monetize the resources that he stole, damaging the ecosystem and the wallet of the operator.
now a few months ago we were in a position where we realized how bad this adoption problem is going to be. In our understanding a nice page with a pretty UI is not gonna cut it
and then on a public call (I think it was Novelty Search?) Const said that in dtao we'll want to have a thousand subnets
if someone plans to validate only on a couple of subnets, great, but there will be global validators and they'll need to run on every subnet

the dividends from running a subnet validator are going to fall and already when we had 32 subnets, when sn1 announced they now need an A100, only 6 validators provided it. This is pre-CHK times, so they couldn't just concentrate stake so they had to WC, pay up or sacrifice APY
now imagine this problem but 30 times worse. Bittensor won't have a thousand subnets unless we figure this out.
that's where sn12 comes in. It will allow SECURE running of GPU validation on most (hopefully all) subnets running on bittensor (and it's brothers and sisters)

the path to that is quite long. Nobody really did anything like that so far, where improper computation (at high speed) would carry heavy penalties and would cause minimal damage (if any at all) to the underlying operation

We need a GPU supercomputer with automatic error detection and correction, built of untrusted, possibly malicious providers which, left unchecked, will jump at the opportunity to explit every small flaw of the system

during the process of building it, validators had issues with deployment of S3 and trusted GPU for verification, sometimes the miners tried to exploit Yuma to harm a validator, we've spent 1% of effort on fighting weight copiers (BTW commit-reveal 3.0 is coming out tomorrow, first subnets are running successfully on testnet today, this week is going to be _history_!)

the scope is massive. Some subnets can use batch processing, but some require streaming where a model is loaded into memory and then inference tasks are performed with low latency as cold-starting the thing on every request is unacceptable

there can be different types of inputs and outputs, so we end up with architecture like this: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/backend-developers-ltd/ComputeHorde/refs/heads/master/docs/streaming_organic_job_full.puml.svg
we also discovered that the proper operation of a high performance validator in the current implementation of Yuma in subtensor will lead to _lower_ dividends
this chart shows that basically the only thing that matters is that you are the biggest validator, so APY is (to an extent) proportional to stake, not to how well you validate
which hurts, among others, Taostats&Corcel validator, as it's not the largest one and is using high quality hardware
so while building the error-correcting supercomputer running on hostile GPU hardware by evil miners which try to shank validators, we have to fix Yuma too 🙄
while fixing the bug in yuma, we found 7 more bugs in yuma 🫠

This is an accurate take on my comments earlier. I do think there is space for this SN51 sort of compute, but it is inherently more dangerous within this eco (imo) if all the miners are aware of the content of the servers. Examples: hijacking OpenAI keys for personal use or for running up costs for the competition. Obtaining S3 bucket credentials, allowing manipulation of performance or results or running up costs. Manipulating weights or other hotkey operations.
There IS market, as runpod and vast.ai show, yet secure compute is ideal. For distributed AI work, there is less to compromise (usually) than validator workloads.

we've also faced some issues, built some tools and learned quite a lot when running an un-pressured subnet with >20k executors (as opposed to like 200 miners othjer typical subnets handle - here it's not going to be enough)

the story continues. The first validator powered by the Horde is partially implemented - it's using a trusted miner and now we are trying to make it work consistently, but sn9 is not so deterministic... the first one was always going to be the hardest
after we figure out one model evaluation subnet, more will follow
meanwhile miners started DDoSing validators and each other
and yes, sometimes we have a bug. We are trying to thread the needle between speed and quality.
sometimes it's the subtensor farm that throws 502 and disrupts the Taostats validator as well as others
sometimes it's in our code
sometimes there is an obscure bug in a dependency of our system that takes ages to diagnose

sometimes a miner reports a bug, but it's actually not a bug but something in his code. Sometimes the miner is correct and we need to fix something. Software needs maintenance and the bigger the software is, the more maintenance it needs.

we also realized that penalizing the miner by making them pay a registration fee is not going to be a good long-term deterrent for malicious actors that aim to target validators or subnets. We need a more effective tool for that, so we've hired a smart contract developer and we are building _another_ piece of infrastructure Bittensor probably should have but doesn't have yet - a slashing functionality

there was a subnet trying to utilize the TEE and they had a compiler which was capable of running payloads on Nvidia cards. I've also seen an entire new protocol which was basically a clone of Akash / runpod / Golem, but using TEE to provide security

the thing is that we all know it will be hacked and it's just a matter of the cost of the attack. It's a new thing, not widely deployed, I wouldn't be surprised if someone presents it on DEFCON in a year or two

there are other fun attack vectors, if you think about it - an attacker able to exploit https could intercept the network communication between the node that he hosts and OpenAI or subtensor. It's not like https was exploit-free all these years, it's just a matter of WHEN, not IF.
If the hotkey and api keys are kept on a cheap CPU machine, the situation is different - a miner can't intercept communication, can't decrypt the payload and steal data from it etc.

let me remind you about an attack in which a state actor with physical access to a machine ripped out a ram stick from a running server and re-plugged it into a hostile motherboard. They realized that yes, RAM needs to be refreshed frequently or it will get its bits garbled, but the garbling is not actually guaranteed and is not reliable, so while there might be some damage, if you replug it fast enough and you are lucky, you can still find enough stuff there for a conviction
so yeah, I don't think TEE is gonna cut it
